_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism

_prev_prog_3.Description:
NH3 S&H (Covered Process 1):



The Facility Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles anhydrous ammonia in a single stationary pressure vessel (PV).  The process equipment includes: (1) one 30,000-gallon PV and ancillary process piping, valves, liquid pump, transfer hoses, volume, temperature, and pressure gauges, and emergency shutdown system (cable operated).



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the (1) monitoring of temperature, volume, and pressures during storage, and (2) transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary PV to Covered Process 2 (Fertilizer Blending).  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Removed pipe reactor from skid and made stationary; constructed new control room and containment; installed updated process monitoring and control systems; re-rated shell and tube heat exchanger
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Classroom training for ammonia awareness and safety.  On the job training for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Written test for classroom training.  Demonstration and observation testing for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Fertilizer Blending (APP) (Covered Process 2):



The Facility Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



Ammonium Polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer is produced by blending anhydrous ammonia with super-phosphoric acid in a reacting chamber and then mixing with water.  The process equipment is physically connected by process piping to the 30,000 gallon stationary anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel.  The process equipment consists of a Stationary Pipe Reactor (SPR) that is owned and operated by the Facility.  The SPR ancillary equipment includes liquid pumps, process piping, reacting chamber, valves, pumps, evaporative cooling tower, flow meters, and pressure and temperature gauges.  The SPR does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia. The APP product is not subject to the RMP rule.



Facility Process Operators: (1) transfer anhydrous ammonia, super phosphoric acid, and water to the SPR; (2) monitor flows, temperatures, and pressures; and (3) transfer APP to storage.  The Facility is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures and maintaining the equipment in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Program.

_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Emergency shutt-off switch to liquid pump
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Classroom training for ammonia awareness and safety.  On the job for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_2.CT_OtherType: Written test for classroom training.  Demonstration and observation for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping and valves, and blenders
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Micronutrient Formulation (Covered Process 4):



The Facility Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMPr combined management plan.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



The fertilizer products are produced by mixing 23% aqua ammonia with water and other ingredients.  The ingredients are transferred to one of two blenders by process piping that discharges into the blenders. The process equipment includes: (1) process piping, valves, and liquid pump; and (2) two stationary blenders and ancillary process piping, valves, liquid pumps, scale, and temperature gauges.  The blenders do not have any storage capabilities for aqua ammonia. 



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of aqua ammonia, water, and other ingredients to the blenders; (2) monitoring of flows and temperatures; and (3) transfer of product to storage.  The Facility is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures and maintaining the equipment in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Program.  The fertilizer product is not subject to the RMP Rule.

_prev_prog_2.CT_OtherType: Written test for classroom training.  Demonstration and observation for Operating Procedures.

_prev_prog_2.Description:
AA S&H (Covered Process 3):



The Facility Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles 23% ammonia concentrated solution in a single 30,000-gallon dedicated aboveground storage tank (ASTs).  The process equipment includes the single AST and ancillary process piping, valves, pump, and volume gauge.   



Aqua ammonia is transferred to the Facility in a commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck operator performs the transfer of aqua ammonia into the AST.  The Facility is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures and maintaining the equipment in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Program.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This EPA RMP was prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r), OSHA 29 CFR ? 1910.119, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68. The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to two of the covered processes operated at this Facility.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident. The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this as a 5-year update in accordance with the rule. All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.   



It is important to note that the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 139,915 lbs, and the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at this Facility is 44,752 lbs (i.e. anhydrous ammonia equivalent).  Although the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 139,915 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 279,830 lbs.  The reason for this is because the single anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel (i.e. 139,915 lbs) is counted a second time to account for the Fertilizer Blending (APP) process that is connected to the single stationary pressure vessel.  Although the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at this Facility is 44,752 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 89,504 lbs.  The reason for this is because the maximum quantity of 23% anhydrous ammonia equivalent (i.e. 44,752 lbs) is counted a second time to account for the Micronutrient Formulation process that is connected to the single stationary AST.



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, fertilizer blending, and dist

ribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammonia concentration) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



Covered Process 1: Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) Storage and Handling

Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending (APP) 

Covered Process 3: Aqua Ammonia (AA) Storage and Handling

Covered Process 4: Micronutrient Formulation



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all four (4) covered processes.  The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released. For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1 and 2), the worst case release was modeled as if the 30,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature. For the aqua ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 3 and 4), the worst case release was modeled as if the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia aboveground storage tank (AST) fails for some reason and releases all contents inside of the secondary containment at the maximum temperature.



The alternative scenario for Covered Process 1 assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to a transfer hose failure during a transfer event from the commercial tanker truck to the pressure vessel.  The alternative scenario for Covered Process 2 assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to a braided hose failure during a transfer event from the pressure vessel to the stationary pipe reactor (SPR).  The alternative scenario for Covered Process 3 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to a transfer hose failure during a transfer event from the commercial tanker truck to the AST.  The alternative scenario for Covered Process 4 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to a process pipe failure during

a transfer event from the AST to a Micronutrient Formulation Blender.  Mitigation by engineering and administrative controls is considered in each of the alternative scenarios.  



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Branch Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Branch Manager is assisted by other trained personnel as directed. The Branch Manager is responsible for ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements as related to their responsibilities.  The accident prevention program elements addressed in the PSM/RMP combined program includes: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
